Pooling Linear ans Logistic Regression Models

Martijn W Heymans

2021-12-03

Source: vignettes/pooling_regressionmodels.Rmd
pooling_regressionmodels.Rmd

Installing the miceafter and mice packages

You can install the development version from GitHub with:

# install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("mwheymans/miceafter")

You can install the released version of mice with:

install.packages("mice")

Examples

  • mice and miceafter for pooling logistic regression models
  • mice and miceafter for pooling linear regression models
  • mice and miceafter for selecting logistic regression models
  • mice and miceafter for selecting linear regression models

mice and miceafter for pooling logistic regression models 


  library(mice)
  library(miceafter)
  
  imp <- mice(lbp_orig, m=5, maxit=5, printFlag = FALSE) 
  
  data_comp <- complete(imp, action = "long", include = FALSE)
  
  library(miceafter)
  pool_lr <- glm_mi(data=data_comp, nimp=5, impvar=".imp", 
                      formula=Chronic ~ factor(Carrying) + Gender + Smoking + 
                      Function + JobControl + JobDemands + SocialSupport, 
                      method="D1", model_type = "binomial")
  pool_lr$RR_model
#> $`Step 1 - no variables removed -`
#>                term    estimate  std.error  statistic        df     p.value
#> 1       (Intercept) -2.82758768 2.78901692 -1.0138295  84.74325 0.313550025
#> 2            Gender -0.24030684 0.44859849 -0.5356836 131.27358 0.593083688
#> 3           Smoking  0.05769304 0.36392155  0.1585315 147.03645 0.874255506
#> 4          Function -0.07164376 0.04671682 -1.5335755 143.83876 0.127330706
#> 5        JobControl  0.00701981 0.02078508  0.3377331 130.05860 0.736108798
#> 6        JobDemands  0.01178877 0.04152767  0.2838773  86.26798 0.777184587
#> 7     SocialSupport  0.06033707 0.05947592  1.0144789 135.53213 0.312161895
#> 8 factor(Carrying)2  1.44590671 0.52836981  2.7365430  88.08747 0.007509334
#> 9 factor(Carrying)3  2.04626110 0.54882633  3.7284310 102.33643 0.000316213
#>           OR    lower.EXP upper.EXP
#> 1 0.05915538 0.0002309884 15.149503
#> 2 0.78638653 0.3237691806  1.910014
#> 3 1.05938975 0.5160769681  2.174689
#> 4 0.93086244 0.8487556583  1.020912
#> 5 1.00704451 0.9664740709  1.049318
#> 6 1.01185853 0.9316837399  1.098933
#> 7 1.06219452 0.9443260075  1.194775
#> 8 4.24570000 1.4857166798 12.132844
#> 9 7.73891192 2.6057215685 22.984327
  pool_lr$multiparm
#> $`Step 1 - no variables removed -`
#>                  p-values D1 F-statistic
#> Gender           0.592241004  0.28695688
#> Smoking          0.874038232  0.02513225
#> Function         0.125158407  2.35185382
#> JobControl       0.735606067  0.11406367
#> JobDemands       0.776732064  0.08058635
#> SocialSupport    0.310442080  1.02916752
#> factor(Carrying) 0.001074164  7.02801533

mice and miceafter for pooling linear regression models 


  library(mice)
  library(miceafter)
  
  imp <- mice(lbp_orig, m=5, maxit=5, printFlag = FALSE) 
  
  data_comp <- complete(imp, action = "long", include = FALSE)
  
  library(miceafter)
  pool_lm <- glm_mi(data=data_comp, nimp=5, impvar=".imp", 
                      formula=Pain ~ Gender + Smoking + Function + 
                      JobControl + JobDemands + SocialSupport, 
                      method="D1", model_type = "linear")
  pool_lm$RR_model
#> $`Step 1 - no variables removed -`
#>            term     estimate  std.error  statistic        df      p.value
#> 1   (Intercept)  7.667680448 2.32843462  3.2930624 129.49734 0.0012778861
#> 2        Gender -0.412986518 0.44698754 -0.9239330  54.01548 0.3596303696
#> 3       Smoking -0.236202457 0.34615097 -0.6823683  87.61111 0.4968062925
#> 4      Function -0.132554806 0.03887208 -3.4100263 134.96654 0.0008570516
#> 5    JobControl -0.015891843 0.02063922 -0.7699826  54.00725 0.4446652174
#> 6    JobDemands  0.013088454 0.03602820  0.3632836 122.52337 0.7170190546
#> 7 SocialSupport -0.008980428 0.05672934 -0.1583031  93.18190 0.8745605708
  pool_lm$multiparm
#> $`Step 1 - no variables removed -`
#>                p-values D1 F-statistic
#> Gender        0.3577818930  0.85365211
#> Smoking       0.4956079076  0.46562654
#> Function      0.0006611488 11.62827940
#> JobControl    0.4431556872  0.59287320
#> JobDemands    0.7164727127  0.13197498
#> SocialSupport 0.8743207099  0.02505986

Back to Examples

mice and miceafter for selecting logistic regression models 


  library(mice)
  library(miceafter)

  imp <- mice(lbp_orig, m=5, maxit=5, printFlag = FALSE) 
  
  data_comp <- complete(imp, action = "long", include = FALSE)
  
  library(miceafter)
  pool_lr <- glm_mi(data=data_comp, nimp=5, impvar=".imp", 
                      formula=Chronic ~ Gender + Smoking + Tampascale + 
                      JobControl + JobDemands + SocialSupport, 
                      p.crit = 0.157, method="D1", 
                      direction = "FW", model_type="binomial")
#> Entered at Step 1 is - Tampascale
#> Entered at Step 2 is - Gender
#> 
#> Selection correctly terminated, 
#> No new variables entered the model
  
  pool_lr$RR_model_final
#> $`Final model`
#>          term    estimate  std.error statistic       df      p.value
#> 1 (Intercept) -11.3841196 1.95555573 -5.821424 142.0747 3.723438e-08
#> 2      Gender  -0.6850866 0.46947884 -1.459249 150.9635 1.465742e-01
#> 3  Tampascale   0.2956884 0.04909685  6.022554 142.9761 1.380524e-08
#>             OR    lower.EXP    upper.EXP
#> 1 1.137469e-05 2.382688e-07 0.0005430153
#> 2 5.040466e-01 1.993518e-01 1.2744453075
#> 3 1.344051e+00 1.219741e+00 1.4810302387
  pool_lr$multiparm_final
#> $`Step 1 - selected - Gender`
#>               p-value D1
#> Gender         0.1445105
#> Smoking        0.8760168
#> JobControl     0.6082749
#> JobDemands     0.5389817
#> SocialSupport  0.8418321

Back to Examples

mice and miceafter for selecting linear regression models 


  library(mice)
  library(miceafter)

  imp <- mice(lbp_orig, m=5, maxit=5, printFlag = FALSE) 
  
  data_comp <- complete(imp, action = "long", include = FALSE)
  
  library(miceafter)
  pool_lm <- glm_mi(data=data_comp, nimp=5, impvar=".imp", 
                    formula=Pain ~ Gender + Smoking + Tampascale + 
                    JobControl + JobDemands + SocialSupport, 
                    p.crit = 0.157, method="D1", 
                    direction = "FW", model_type = "linear")
#> Entered at Step 1 is - Tampascale
#> 
#> Selection correctly terminated, 
#> No new variables entered the model
  
  pool_lm$RR_model_final
#> $`Final model`
#>          term   estimate  std.error statistic       df      p.value
#> 1 (Intercept) -7.5299523 0.71838581 -10.48177 32.76921 5.345724e-12
#> 2  Tampascale  0.3263506 0.01805264  18.07773 36.56396 0.000000e+00
  pool_lm$multiparm_final
#> $`Step 0 - selected - Tampascale`
#>                 p-value D1
#> Gender        2.262993e-01
#> Smoking       4.355665e-01
#> Tampascale    1.384245e-24
#> JobControl    2.877343e-01
#> JobDemands    3.315305e-01
#> SocialSupport 9.318923e-01
